benefits.title: Ginseng modifies the diabetic phenotype and genes associated with diabetes in the male ZDF rat.
benefits.summary: Ginseng modified the diabetic phenotype and genes associated with diabetes in male ZDF rats, decreasing cholesterol levels and potentially having therapeutic value in treating human diabetes.
benefits.journal: Phytomedicine : international journal of phytotherapy and phytopharmacology

benefits.title: Ginseng pharmacology: multiple constituents and multiple actions.
benefits.summary: Ginseng's beneficial effects are due to its ginsenosides, which target various tissues and produce an array of pharmacological responses.

benefits.title: A review on the medicinal potentials of ginseng and ginsenosides on cardiovascular diseases
benefits.summary: Ginseng has potentially positive effects on heart disease through its properties like antioxidation, reduced platelet adhesion, vasomotor regulation, improving lipid profiles, and influencing various ion channels.

benefits.title: Ginseng: potential for the enhancement of cognitive performance and mood
benefits.summary: Single doses of ginseng can improve memory, but can also cause attention task deficits.

benefits.title: Efficacy and safety of ginseng
benefits.summary: Ginseng can combat stress, enhance central and immune systems, and contribute towards maintaining optimal oxidative status against chronic disease states and aging.

benefits.title: Cardiovascular Diseases and Panax ginseng: A Review on Molecular Mechanisms and Medical Applications
benefits.summary: Ginseng may be potentially valuable in treating cardiovascular diseases through diverse mechanisms such as antioxidation, modifying vasomotor function, reducing platelet adhesion, influencing ion channels, altering autonomic neurotransmitters release, and improving lipid profiles.

benefits.title: Beneficial effects of Panax ginseng for the treatment and prevention of neurodegenerative diseases: past findings and future directions
benefits.summary: Ginseng's beneficial effects on neurodegenerative diseases are attributed to its antioxidative and immunomodulatory activities of its ginsenoside components.

benefits.title: Therapeutic Potential of Ginseng in the Management of Cardiovascular Disorders
benefits.summary: Ginseng benefits include cardioprotection, antihypertensive effects, and attenuation of myocardial hypertrophy and heart failure.

benefits.title: Adaptogenic herb ginseng (Panax) as medical food: Status quo and future prospects.
benefits.summary: Ginseng has antioxidant, anti-inflammation, anti-fatigue, antidiabetic, antitumor, immunomodulation, anti-obesity, cardioprotective, antimicrobial, neuroprotective, and aphrodisiac properties.

benefits.title: Chemical Structures and Pharmacological Profiles of Ginseng Saponins
benefits.summary: Ginseng saponins play a significant role in exerting multiple therapeutic effects, including boosting physical vitality and improving quality of life.

side effects.title: Ginseng phytochemicals as therapeutics in oncology: Recent perspectives.
side effects.summary: Ginseng aids in reducing alopecia, fatigue, and nausea, side effects of chemotherapeutic drugs.

side effects.title: Menometrorrhagia and tachyarrhythmia after using oral and topical ginseng.
side effects.summary: Ginseng use can cause menometrorrhagia and tachyarrhythmia, but this could be coincidental.

side effects.title: Herbal Products and Serious Side Effects: A Case of Ginseng‐Induced Manic Episode
side effects.summary: Ginseng consumption can lead to manic symptoms and other potentially harmful side effects.

side effects.title: The aphrodisiac and adaptogenic properties of ginseng.
side effects.summary: Ginseng side effects include hypertension, diarrhea, restlessness, mastalgia, and vaginal bleeding.

side effects.title: Red ginseng protects against cisplatin-induced intestinal toxicity by inhibiting apoptosis and autophagy via the PI3K/AKT and MAPK signaling pathways.
side effects.summary: Red ginseng can relieve symptoms of cisplatin-induced intestinal damage, such as loss of body weight, shrinkage of the small intestine, and increased intestinal function index.

side effects.title: The Association Between Ginseng and Mania: A Case Report and Literature Review
side effects.summary: Ginseng consumption can lead to mania with psychotic features, such as increased psychomotor activity, anxious mood, unstable affect, irritability, aggression, and persecutory delusions.

side effects.title: Ginseng alleviates cyclophosphamide-induced hepatotoxicity via reversing disordered homeostasis of glutathione and bile acid
side effects.summary: Ginseng alleviates cyclophosphamide-induced hepatotoxicity by modulating the disordered homeostasis of GSH and bile acid, potentially by inducing the expression of NRF 2 in liver.

side effects.title: Ginseng improves pulmonary functions and exercise capacity in patients with COPD.
side effects.summary: Ginseng extract (G115) improved pulmonary functions, maximum voluntary ventilation, maximum inspiratory pressure, and maximal oxygen consumption in patients with moderately-severe COPD without side effects.
side effects.journal: Monaldi archives for chest disease = Archivio Monaldi per le malattie del torace

side effects.title: Adaptogenic effects of Panax ginseng on modulation of cardiovascular functions
side effects.summary: Panax ginseng has immunomodulatory, neuromodulatory, and cardioprotective effects, suppresses anxiety, and balances vascular tone.

side effects.title: The ginseng's fireness is associated with the lowering activity of liver Na(+)-K(+)-ATPase.
side effects.summary: Ginseng's fireness is associated with the lowering activity of liver Na(+)-K(+)-ATPase.

dosage.title: Effects of Korean Red Ginseng on Cognitive and Motor Function: A Double-blind, Randomized, Placebo-controlled Trial
dosage.summary: A daily dose of 4,500 mg red ginseng was used in this study.

dosage.title: The effects of Panax ginseng on quality of life
dosage.summary: Panax ginseng has been evaluated at dosages of 80-400 mg for quality of life improvement.
dosage.journal: Journal of Clinical Pharmacy and Therapeutics

dosage.title: Ginseng and Cancer-Related Fatigue: A Systematic Review of Clinical Trials
dosage.summary: Consuming 2000 mg/day of American ginseng, 400 mg/day of Asian ginseng, and 3000 mg/day of Korean ginseng significantly reduced cancer-related fatigue symptoms.

dosage.title: Chronic toxicity of ginsenoside Re on Sprague-Dawley rats.
dosage.summary: Ginsenoside Re is well tolerated up to a 375 mg/kg/day oral dosage level and non-toxic in both male and female rats.

dosage.title: Genenal Pharmacological Action of Ginseng Preparation
dosage.summary: Ginseng preparation showed no analgesic activity in doses of 300 and 900mg/kg, but had a hypothermic action only in 900mg/kg dose.

dosage.title: No ergogenic effects of ginseng (Panax ginseng C.A. Meyer) during graded maximal aerobic exercise.
dosage.summary: Ginseng supplementation at dosages of 200 or 400 mg/day did not show any effect on physiologic and psychological parameters during graded maximal aerobic exercise.
dosage.journal: Journal of the American Dietetic Association

dosage.title: The anti-hypertensive effect of ginseng in patients with mild hypertension
dosage.summary: Ginseng can be useful for mild hypertension at a dosage of 4.5g per day, with Korean and Chinese ginseng showing more excellent effects.

dosage.title: Dissipation, residues, and safety evaluation of trifloxystrobin and tebuconazole on ginseng and soil
dosage.summary: Nativo 75 WG use on ginseng at a dosage of 150-225 g a.i. ha1 is unlikely to cause health problems.

dosage.title: A 4-Week, Repeated, Intravenous Dose, Toxicity Test of Mountain Ginseng Pharmacopuncture in Sprague-Dawley Rats
dosage.summary: The high and low doses of mountain ginseng pharmacopuncture should be 10 mL/kg and 2.5 mL/kg, respectively, for a 13-week, repeated test.

dosage.title: Ginsengs: A Review of Safety and Efficacy
dosage.summary: The recommended daily dose for Korean ginseng is 0.5 to 2 g per day of dried root or 100 to 300 mg per day of a standardized extract, and for Siberian ginseng, 2 to 3 g per day of dried root or equivalent preparations.
